values.description:
I accidentally [broke the pkg-config tests on OS X](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-default-devel-homebrew-amd64-2/40/) by adding `tbb` to the `Requires` list in pull request #1642. Debian/Ubuntu provide a pkg-config file for `tbb`, though one is not provided upstream. The [Fedora folks are working to push one upstream](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=825402). In the meantime, we can just include `tbb` in the pkg-config file if we actually found its pkg-config file on this platform.

I also fixed most of the other clang warnings on osx.
values.title: Only add tbb to pkg-config file if we can find it on this platform

summary.raw:
I accidentally [broke the pkg-config tests on OS X](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-default-devel-homebrew-amd64-2/40/) by adding `tbb` to the `Requires` list in pull request #1642. Debian/Ubuntu provide a pkg-config file for `tbb`, though one is not provided upstream. The [Fedora folks are working to push one upstream](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=825402). In the meantime, we can just include `tbb` in the pkg-config file if we actually found its pkg-config file on this platform.

I also fixed most of the other clang warnings on osx.
summary.html:
I accidentally broke the pkg-config tests on OS X by adding tbb to the Requires list in pull request #1642. Debian/Ubuntu provide a pkg-config file for tbb, though one is not provided upstream. The Fedora folks are working to push one upstream. In the meantime, we can just include tbb in the pkg-config file if we actually found its pkg-config file on this platform.

I also fixed most of the other clang warnings on osx.

values.description:
**Ignore this pull request unless you're working on the foosball demo**

* Shake table while holding both hydra triggers

* Reset ball by pressing both hydra joysticks at the same time and then releasing

I was just thinking that in the future, it might be nice to sync both players and only do these actions if both players are doing it at the same time, to prevent someone ruining the game.

* Also added a parameter to easily change the power of table shaking

This works best with `gazebo_models` [pull request 148](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/148)
values.title: [DRC Expo: Foosball] Shake shake shake

summary.raw:
**Ignore this pull request unless you're working on the foosball demo**

* Shake table while holding both hydra triggers

* Reset ball by pressing both hydra joysticks at the same time and then releasing

I was just thinking that in the future, it might be nice to sync both players and only do these actions if both players are doing it at the same time, to prevent someone ruining the game.

* Also added a parameter to easily change the power of table shaking

This works best with `gazebo_models` [pull request 148](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/148)
summary.html:
Ignore this pull request unless you're working on the foosball demo

  • Shake table while holding both hydra triggers

  • Reset ball by pressing both hydra joysticks at the same time and then releasing

I was just thinking that in the future, it might be nice to sync both players and only do these actions if both players are doing it at the same time, to prevent someone ruining the game.

  • Also added a parameter to easily change the power of table shaking

This works best with gazebo_models pull request 148

values.description:
Pull request #1584 added the option to show and hide toolbars.

This pull request adds an event which the main window is connected to and triggers this action. This way it can be easily used by plugins, such as the [DRC Foosball demo](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1706/drc-expo-foosball-start-demo-in-full/diff) and the [DRC HAPTIX demo](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/handsim/pull-request/127/drc-finals-demo-start-in-full-screen/diff).
values.title: Event to show top and bottom toolbars

summary.raw:
Pull request #1584 added the option to show and hide toolbars.

This pull request adds an event which the main window is connected to and triggers this action. This way it can be easily used by plugins, such as the [DRC Foosball demo](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1706/drc-expo-foosball-start-demo-in-full/diff) and the [DRC HAPTIX demo](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/handsim/pull-request/127/drc-finals-demo-start-in-full-screen/diff).
summary.html:
Pull request #1584 added the option to show and hide toolbars.

This pull request adds an event which the main window is connected to and triggers this action. This way it can be easily used by plugins, such as the DRC Foosball demo and the DRC HAPTIX demo.

values.description:
Issue #1570 happens because it is possible to get `GLWidget` to keep publishing and subscribing to selection messages in a loop. 

An easy way to reproduce this is to insert a Rag Doll in the scene and then double click it. If you click fast enough you'll see bounding boxes blinking uncontrolably, sometimes Gazebo even crashes. You can even check the messages being circularly published with `gz topic -e /gazebo/default/selection`.

After talking to @nkoenig about this, we thought it would be a nice idea to stop subscribing to selection messages from the client side, but keep on publishing them. This means clients won't get selection messages from other clients for example, so they can't see each other's selections. Which is probably something which shouldn't be happening right now, since gzclient doesn't really support collaboration yet.

For reference, publishing selection messages was introduced on pull request #1318. Publishing will be maintained, only subscribing is being removed.

I also removed `hoverVis` from `GLWidget` since it isn't used.

This should also close issue #1523
values.title: Unsubscribe from selection msgs

summary.raw:
Issue #1570 happens because it is possible to get `GLWidget` to keep publishing and subscribing to selection messages in a loop. 

An easy way to reproduce this is to insert a Rag Doll in the scene and then double click it. If you click fast enough you'll see bounding boxes blinking uncontrolably, sometimes Gazebo even crashes. You can even check the messages being circularly published with `gz topic -e /gazebo/default/selection`.

After talking to @nkoenig about this, we thought it would be a nice idea to stop subscribing to selection messages from the client side, but keep on publishing them. This means clients won't get selection messages from other clients for example, so they can't see each other's selections. Which is probably something which shouldn't be happening right now, since gzclient doesn't really support collaboration yet.

For reference, publishing selection messages was introduced on pull request #1318. Publishing will be maintained, only subscribing is being removed.

I also removed `hoverVis` from `GLWidget` since it isn't used.

This should also close issue #1523
summary.html:
Issue #1570 happens because it is possible to get GLWidget to keep publishing and subscribing to selection messages in a loop.

An easy way to reproduce this is to insert a Rag Doll in the scene and then double click it. If you click fast enough you'll see bounding boxes blinking uncontrolably, sometimes Gazebo even crashes. You can even check the messages being circularly published with gz topic -e /gazebo/default/selection.

After talking to @nkoenig about this, we thought it would be a nice idea to stop subscribing to selection messages from the client side, but keep on publishing them. This means clients won't get selection messages from other clients for example, so they can't see each other's selections. Which is probably something which shouldn't be happening right now, since gzclient doesn't really support collaboration yet.

For reference, publishing selection messages was introduced on pull request #1318. Publishing will be maintained, only subscribing is being removed.

I also removed hoverVis from GLWidget since it isn't used.

This should also close issue #1523

values.description:
`underwater.world` now has a greenish-blue tint.

A check has been added to `LiftDragPlugin` to ensure that the world update connection doesn't get made if the link specified in SDF was not found.
values.title: Change ambient color of underwater.world, fix LiftDragPlugin segfault

summary.raw:
`underwater.world` now has a greenish-blue tint.

A check has been added to `LiftDragPlugin` to ensure that the world update connection doesn't get made if the link specified in SDF was not found.
summary.html:
underwater.world now has a greenish-blue tint.

A check has been added to LiftDragPlugin to ensure that the world update connection doesn't get made if the link specified in SDF was not found.

values.description:
While working on the log playback tool, I felt the need for a global and versatile function to format time. In fact, there are variants implemented in several places, so I think it's a good idea to have it in a common place.

Added `Time::FormattedString` with the option to show/hide different elements (day, hour, min, sec, msec). Note that there's already a `Time::GetWallTimeAsISOString`, which uses a slightly different format.

Removed `TimePanel::FormatTime`, `TimerGUIPlugin::FormatTime` and `RestWebPlugin::FormatTime`, which were all doing similar things, and used the new function instead.
values.title: Move FormatTime to Time class

summary.raw:
While working on the log playback tool, I felt the need for a global and versatile function to format time. In fact, there are variants implemented in several places, so I think it's a good idea to have it in a common place.

Added `Time::FormattedString` with the option to show/hide different elements (day, hour, min, sec, msec). Note that there's already a `Time::GetWallTimeAsISOString`, which uses a slightly different format.

Removed `TimePanel::FormatTime`, `TimerGUIPlugin::FormatTime` and `RestWebPlugin::FormatTime`, which were all doing similar things, and used the new function instead.
summary.html:
While working on the log playback tool, I felt the need for a global and versatile function to format time. In fact, there are variants implemented in several places, so I think it's a good idea to have it in a common place.

Added Time::FormattedString with the option to show/hide different elements (day, hour, min, sec, msec). Note that there's already a Time::GetWallTimeAsISOString, which uses a slightly different format.

Removed TimePanel::FormatTime, TimerGUIPlugin::FormatTime and RestWebPlugin::FormatTime, which were all doing similar things, and used the new function instead.

values.title: Update default fluid density value

values.description:
* CessnaPlugin: Allow control of the thrust (0-100%) and control surfaces from -30deg to 30deg. The propeller has a velocity PID to maintain RPMs, while the control surfaces have position PIDs.

* CessnaGUIPlugin: Cessna control using the keyboard:
  
    * 'a': Increase thrust.
    * 'z': Decrease thrust.
    * 's': Increase flaps.
    * 'x': Decrease flaps.
    * 'd': Increase elevators.
    * 'c': Decrease elevators.
    * 'f': Increase rudder.
    * 'v': Decrease rudder.

For the shake of simplicity, left and wing flaps and ailerons are coupled when we press 's' or 'x'. The plugin allows independent control if needed.

There's a sample world file available named `cessna_demo.world`. 
   
Note for pilots: the plane is not going to fly yet. We'll add the `liftDragPlugin` in the next pull request.
values.title: Plugin to control the Cessna model

summary.raw:
* CessnaPlugin: Allow control of the thrust (0-100%) and control surfaces from -30deg to 30deg. The propeller has a velocity PID to maintain RPMs, while the control surfaces have position PIDs.

* CessnaGUIPlugin: Cessna control using the keyboard:
  
    * 'a': Increase thrust.
    * 'z': Decrease thrust.
    * 's': Increase flaps.
    * 'x': Decrease flaps.
    * 'd': Increase elevators.
    * 'c': Decrease elevators.
    * 'f': Increase rudder.
    * 'v': Decrease rudder.

For the shake of simplicity, left and wing flaps and ailerons are coupled when we press 's' or 'x'. The plugin allows independent control if needed.

There's a sample world file available named `cessna_demo.world`. 
   
Note for pilots: the plane is not going to fly yet. We'll add the `liftDragPlugin` in the next pull request.
summary.html:
• CessnaPlugin: Allow control of the thrust (0-100%) and control surfaces from -30deg to 30deg. The propeller has a velocity PID to maintain RPMs, while the control surfaces have position PIDs.

  • CessnaGUIPlugin: Cessna control using the keyboard:

    • 'a': Increase thrust.
    • 'z': Decrease thrust.
    • 's': Increase flaps.
    • 'x': Decrease flaps.
    • 'd': Increase elevators.
    • 'c': Decrease elevators.
    • 'f': Increase rudder.
    • 'v': Decrease rudder.

For the shake of simplicity, left and wing flaps and ailerons are coupled when we press 's' or 'x'. The plugin allows independent control if needed.

There's a sample world file available named cessna_demo.world.

Note for pilots: the plane is not going to fly yet. We'll add the liftDragPlugin in the next pull request.

values.description:
Fullscreen and Show toolbar actions can be triggered by shortcuts (F11 / Ctrl+H), from the menu or through events.

The events weren't updating the actions though, so if you start a world in fullscreen (event) for example, when you click F11 to leave fullscreen, it doesn't work at the first click, but works in the second.

This pull request makes sure everything is synced.

This is currently being used in the Foosball and HAPTIX demos.
values.title: Update fullscreen and show toolbars actions after event

summary.raw:
Fullscreen and Show toolbar actions can be triggered by shortcuts (F11 / Ctrl+H), from the menu or through events.

The events weren't updating the actions though, so if you start a world in fullscreen (event) for example, when you click F11 to leave fullscreen, it doesn't work at the first click, but works in the second.

This pull request makes sure everything is synced.

This is currently being used in the Foosball and HAPTIX demos.
summary.html:
Fullscreen and Show toolbar actions can be triggered by shortcuts (F11 / Ctrl+H), from the menu or through events.

The events weren't updating the actions though, so if you start a world in fullscreen (event) for example, when you click F11 to leave fullscreen, it doesn't work at the first click, but works in the second.

This pull request makes sure everything is synced.

This is currently being used in the Foosball and HAPTIX demos.

values.title: changelog for pull request #1561 (parallelize position projection error correction with threads)

values.description:
Courtesy of Hsu airlines.

Requires [this pull request](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/153) from Gazebo models.

GUI plugin changes:

* Now, the increments/decrements are based on the current state of the model.
* Roll control.
* Three presets for take-off, cruise and landing.
* Arrow keys control.

Cessna msg changes:

* The message contains the current values observed and the target values commanded by a controller.

LiftDragPluginChanges:

* The plugin now modifies its coeficients based on the angle of the joints. This allows to modify the drag/lift properties when we change the angle of the control surfaces.

Cessna world:

* It contains all the LiftDrag plugins.

[Here's the video](https://youtu.be/iMHGnEhOIhs).

[Tutorial available here](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-request/224).
values.title: Cessna model ready to fly

[test failure](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-default-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/94/testReport/%28root%29/OgreLog/PubSub/)

~~~
$ grep -i error ~/.gazebo/ogre.log 
10:18:04: Compiler error: invalid parameters in gazebo.material(1444):
 anistropic not supported as first argument
 (must be "none", "bilinear", "trilinear", or "anisotropic")
~~~

values.description:
http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-default-devel-trusty-amd64/48/warnings17Result/new/

~~~
declaration of 'linkName' shadows a member of 'this' [-Wshadow]
~~~

This was caused by 48be585, which converted to using local instead of member variables, but it looks like `linkName` wasn't deleted when it should have been.

values.description:
Fixed issue [1613](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/1613/physicslinktestaddforce-0-race-condition).  

The failing case happens when `m=0`, where the `caccel` is allocated [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/9b24ef53cd54c6fcb7dfe2db5b32107cb1de0779/deps/opende/src/quickstep.cpp#cl-251) and initialized inside the `for (m>0)` loop. 

Fix tested on my desktop with 200 repeat run of  
$ for i in `seq 200`; do ./build_isolated/gazebo/devel/test/integration/INTEGRATION_physics_link --gtest_filter='*AddForce/0'; done   
All the 200 tests passed without fail
values.title: Fixed issue 1613

summary.raw:
Fixed issue [1613](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/1613/physicslinktestaddforce-0-race-condition).  

The failing case happens when `m=0`, where the `caccel` is allocated [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/9b24ef53cd54c6fcb7dfe2db5b32107cb1de0779/deps/opende/src/quickstep.cpp#cl-251) and initialized inside the `for (m>0)` loop. 

Fix tested on my desktop with 200 repeat run of  
$ for i in `seq 200`; do ./build_isolated/gazebo/devel/test/integration/INTEGRATION_physics_link --gtest_filter='*AddForce/0'; done   
All the 200 tests passed without fail
summary.html:
Fixed issue 1613.

The failing case happens when m=0, where the caccel is allocated here and initialized inside the for (m>0) loop.

Fix tested on my desktop with 200 repeat run of
$ for i in seq 200; do ./build_isolated/gazebo/devel/test/integration/INTEGRATION_physics_link --gtest_filter='*AddForce/0'; done
All the 200 tests passed without fail

values.title: cache joint force torque for ode and dart
values.reason: This pull request is close to a year old. Someone can revive this if/when they have time.

values.description:
Simulation iterations was not included in `State`. This pull requests adds it and add the following public functions to LogPlay:

* HasIterations() This is required for compatibility with old log files that doesn't have `<iterations>` in its state. During a playback, if a log file has `<iterations>`, the value contained in the log file is used to update the `iterations` value of the world. If the log file doesn't contain `<iterations>`, we assume that `iterations` start from 0 and we manually increment it in each log step.

* GetInitialIterations() Initial `<iterations>` value contained in the log file. This will be `0` if the log files does not have the `<iterations>` tag.
values.title: Add simulation iterations to state

summary.raw:
Simulation iterations was not included in `State`. This pull requests adds it and add the following public functions to LogPlay:

* HasIterations() This is required for compatibility with old log files that doesn't have `<iterations>` in its state. During a playback, if a log file has `<iterations>`, the value contained in the log file is used to update the `iterations` value of the world. If the log file doesn't contain `<iterations>`, we assume that `iterations` start from 0 and we manually increment it in each log step.

* GetInitialIterations() Initial `<iterations>` value contained in the log file. This will be `0` if the log files does not have the `<iterations>` tag.
summary.html:
Simulation iterations was not included in State. This pull requests adds it and add the following public functions to LogPlay:

  • HasIterations() This is required for compatibility with old log files that doesn't have <iterations> in its state. During a playback, if a log file has <iterations>, the value contained in the log file is used to update the iterations value of the world. If the log file doesn't contain <iterations>, we assume that iterations start from 0 and we manually increment it in each log step.

  • GetInitialIterations() Initial <iterations> value contained in the log file. This will be 0 if the log files does not have the <iterations> tag.

values.description:
The `INTEGRATION_worlds_installed` test has been failing on default for the past 5 days with timeouts ([example build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-default-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/102/testReport/junit/(root)/INTEGRATION_worlds_installed/test_ran/)). I was able to reproduce the failure by clearing `~/.gazebo/models` so that it has to download all the models. I observed a run take over 400 seconds on my desktop with this procedure. So I've increased the test timeout to 700 seconds.

I tested this branch in jenkins before creating the pull request, and the test [passed in 4 min 15 sec](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/321/testReport/(root)/WorldsInstalled/checkWorlds/). Since this isn't the first test to run, I think other tests cause some of the other models to be already downloaded, which can explain why it didn't take the 400 seconds that I observed on my desktop.

In addition, I added a print statement with the name of each world file to aid in debugging. Before, it was failing with no console output at all.

I'll post additional jenkins results as they become available.
values.title: Fix INTEGRATION_worlds_installed timeouts

summary.raw:
The `INTEGRATION_worlds_installed` test has been failing on default for the past 5 days with timeouts ([example build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-default-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/102/testReport/junit/(root)/INTEGRATION_worlds_installed/test_ran/)). I was able to reproduce the failure by clearing `~/.gazebo/models` so that it has to download all the models. I observed a run take over 400 seconds on my desktop with this procedure. So I've increased the test timeout to 700 seconds.

I tested this branch in jenkins before creating the pull request, and the test [passed in 4 min 15 sec](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/321/testReport/(root)/WorldsInstalled/checkWorlds/). Since this isn't the first test to run, I think other tests cause some of the other models to be already downloaded, which can explain why it didn't take the 400 seconds that I observed on my desktop.

In addition, I added a print statement with the name of each world file to aid in debugging. Before, it was failing with no console output at all.

I'll post additional jenkins results as they become available.
summary.html:
The INTEGRATION_worlds_installed test has been failing on default for the past 5 days with timeouts (example build). I was able to reproduce the failure by clearing ~/.gazebo/models so that it has to download all the models. I observed a run take over 400 seconds on my desktop with this procedure. So I've increased the test timeout to 700 seconds.

I tested this branch in jenkins before creating the pull request, and the test passed in 4 min 15 sec. Since this isn't the first test to run, I think other tests cause some of the other models to be already downloaded, which can explain why it didn't take the 400 seconds that I observed on my desktop.

In addition, I added a print statement with the name of each world file to aid in debugging. Before, it was failing with no console output at all.

I'll post additional jenkins results as they become available.

values.description:
I propose that the GPS sensor be changed to make use of the ```noises``` vector provided by the base ```Sensor``` class. Currently, the sensor does not make use of the noises vector, and only one noise model is used to generate errors for both latitude and longitude position (likewise for velocity). This makes it difficult to create independent custom noise callbacks for latitude and longitude.

The reason that I am requesting this change now, is that it makes the GPS sensor compatible with the [crates_gnss](https://bitbucket.org/asymingt/crates_gnss) plugin I have just released, which generates space and time correlated GPS position and velocity perturbations using traces of broadcast/precise satellite ephemerides and clocks, as well as ionospheric total electron count.
values.title: Switch to six independent GPS sensor noise models

summary.raw:
I propose that the GPS sensor be changed to make use of the ```noises``` vector provided by the base ```Sensor``` class. Currently, the sensor does not make use of the noises vector, and only one noise model is used to generate errors for both latitude and longitude position (likewise for velocity). This makes it difficult to create independent custom noise callbacks for latitude and longitude.

The reason that I am requesting this change now, is that it makes the GPS sensor compatible with the [crates_gnss](https://bitbucket.org/asymingt/crates_gnss) plugin I have just released, which generates space and time correlated GPS position and velocity perturbations using traces of broadcast/precise satellite ephemerides and clocks, as well as ionospheric total electron count.
summary.html:
I propose that the GPS sensor be changed to make use of the noises vector provided by the base Sensor class. Currently, the sensor does not make use of the noises vector, and only one noise model is used to generate errors for both latitude and longitude position (likewise for velocity). This makes it difficult to create independent custom noise callbacks for latitude and longitude.

The reason that I am requesting this change now, is that it makes the GPS sensor compatible with the crates_gnss plugin I have just released, which generates space and time correlated GPS position and velocity perturbations using traces of broadcast/precise satellite ephemerides and clocks, as well as ionospheric total electron count.

values.description:
The test is [failing in jenkins](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-default-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/111/testReport/junit/%28root%29/gzTest/SDF/). This has happened to me before. This part of the test prints out [test/worlds/empty_different_name.world](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/1e71620459fa392ec1ec6a30df84d75e0086615d/test/worlds/empty_different_name.world?at=default).
I believe it can fail because the [ground_plane model in gazebo_models](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/src/74a580447dd670bc78f9f9e476a6d5d3ffd69563/ground_plane/model.sdf?at=default) differs from the [one hosted in gazebo](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/1e71620459fa392ec1ec6a30df84d75e0086615d/models/ground_plane/model.sdf?at=default), so you can get different shasums depending on which model is included.

~~This pull request is another band-aid.~~

Update: I changed from using `empty_different_name.world` to `box_plane_low_friction_test.world`, which doesn't `<include>` any model files, so the test should give more consistent results.

* [new jenkins run](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/352/): clean
values.title: Fix last shasum in gzTest.SDF

This has happened to me before. This part of the test prints out [test/worlds/empty_different_name.world](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/1e71620459fa392ec1ec6a30df84d75e0086615d/test/worlds/empty_different_name.world?at=default).
I believe it can fail because the [ground_plane model in gazebo_models](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/src/74a580447dd670bc78f9f9e476a6d5d3ffd69563/ground_plane/model.sdf?at=default) differs from the [one hosted in gazebo](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/1e71620459fa392ec1ec6a30df84d75e0086615d/models/ground_plane/model.sdf?at=default), so you can get different shasums depending on which model is included.

~~This pull request is another band-aid.~~

Update: I changed from using `empty_different_name.world` to `box_plane_low_friction_test.world`, which doesn't `<include>` any model files, so the test should give more consistent results.

* [new jenkins run](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/352/): clean
summary.html:
The test is failing in jenkins. This has happened to me before. This part of the test prints out test/worlds/empty_different_name.world. I believe it can fail because the ground_plane model in gazebo_models differs from the one hosted in gazebo, so you can get different shasums depending on which model is included.

This pull request is another band-aid.

Update: I changed from using empty_different_name.world to box_plane_low_friction_test.world, which doesn't <include> any model files, so the test should give more consistent results.

  • new jenkins run: clean

values.description:
* [Tutorial](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=apply_force_torque&cat=tools_utilities)

* Pull request history:

    * Pull request #1506 was supposed to introduce all features at once but was declined because several issues were found

    * Pull request #1600 added the dialog without visuals

    * Pull request #1619 added visuals which move in response to the dialog

    * Pull request #1699 added a few simple mouse interactions

* This pull request:

    * Introduces the draggable pink circles and the necessary mouse events (press and move)

    * Adds the concept of `mode`, which means what the circles are attached to

    * Adds the concept of `active`, which is for the case when several dialogs are open at the same time and only one can be active at a time

    * Introduces the difference between rotation by mouse and by dialog

    * Added tests for most new functions (only `NewForceDirection` is not covered, because it's analogous to `NewTorqueDirection`). But! The test passes consistently on my desktop, but fails in different places at each jenkins run... Not sure how to fix that, help appreciated :)

        * [Build 179](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64/179/), test [fails](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64/179/testReport/%28root%29/ApplyWrenchDialog_TEST/MouseInteractions/) on line 456
        * [Build 180](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64/180/), test [fails](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64/180/testReport/%28root%29/ApplyWrenchDialog_TEST/MouseInteractions/) on line 580
        * [Build 184](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64/184/), test [fails](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64/184/testReport/%28root%29/ApplyWrenchDialog_TEST/MouseInteractions/) on line 471
        * **UPDATE**: [Build 113](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/113/testReport/junit/%28root%29/ApplyWrenchDialog_TEST/MouseInteractions/) Just saw that `isActiveWindow` fails sporadically(?) on default
values.title: Rotate force/torque with mouse on Apply Force/Torque dialog

values.description:
Similar for what we do in [sdformat](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/173/convert-to-use-ignition-math/diff#chg-configure.bat) when using the ignition-math zip, we can not use the cmake module. configure.bat is in charge of inject the variables directly.

* Testing run on [default branch](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-windows7-amd64/25/)
* Testing run on [this branch](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-windows7-amd64/27/console). Still need more fixes.

* Testing run on [default branch](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-windows7-amd64/25/)
* Testing run on [this branch](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-windows7-amd64/27/console). Still need more fixes.

values.description:
pull request #1614 introduced `VisualType`. It assumed that all visual msgs published to the `~/visual` topic are of type `VT_VISUAL`. This turns out to be an incorrect assumption since all `Entities` also publish to "~/visual" on `Load`. 

This PR resolves this by adding a `type` field to `visual.proto` to help distinguish between different visuals.

Expanded a couple of tests to verify visual types.
values.title: Add type to visual msg

summary.raw:
pull request #1614 introduced `VisualType`. It assumed that all visual msgs published to the `~/visual` topic are of type `VT_VISUAL`. This turns out to be an incorrect assumption since all `Entities` also publish to "~/visual" on `Load`. 

This PR resolves this by adding a `type` field to `visual.proto` to help distinguish between different visuals.

Expanded a couple of tests to verify visual types.
summary.html:
pull request #1614 introduced VisualType. It assumed that all visual msgs published to the ~/visual topic are of type VT_VISUAL. This turns out to be an incorrect assumption since all Entities also publish to "~/visual" on Load.

This PR resolves this by adding a type field to visual.proto to help distinguish between different visuals.

Expanded a couple of tests to verify visual types.

values.description:
When issue #1514 was fixed, the import image dialog was forgotten, probably because it was introduced in Gazebo 5 and all other dialogs were fixed from Gazebo 4.1. See [this question](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/8931/cant-import-images-in-building-editor/).

It was recently reported on the issue that the problem persists when trying to save the world, but I wasn't able to reproduce that. Could it be that the user is using an old Gazebo 5 build? 

I also fixed a crash I just found when trying to save an empty building on Gazebo5.
values.title: Fixed ImportImageDialog's browse and crashing when trying to save empty building

summary.raw:
When issue #1514 was fixed, the import image dialog was forgotten, probably because it was introduced in Gazebo 5 and all other dialogs were fixed from Gazebo 4.1. See [this question](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/8931/cant-import-images-in-building-editor/).

It was recently reported on the issue that the problem persists when trying to save the world, but I wasn't able to reproduce that. Could it be that the user is using an old Gazebo 5 build? 

I also fixed a crash I just found when trying to save an empty building on Gazebo5.
summary.html:
When issue #1514 was fixed, the import image dialog was forgotten, probably because it was introduced in Gazebo 5 and all other dialogs were fixed from Gazebo 4.1. See this question.

It was recently reported on the issue that the problem persists when trying to save the world, but I wasn't able to reproduce that. Could it be that the user is using an old Gazebo 5 build?

I also fixed a crash I just found when trying to save an empty building on Gazebo5.

values.description:
This pull request adds the backend implementation for:

  1. Rewind: The simulation starts from the beginning.
  1. Forward: The simulation jumps to the end of the log file.
  1. Seek: The simulation jumps to a specific point specified by its simulation time.

There's still no easy way to test it until we have all the GUI changes merged. This is how you can do it:

Replace `MainWindow.cc::Step()` with this snippet:


```
#!c++
void MainWindow::Step()
{
  msgs::LogPlaybackControl msg;
  msg.set_rewind(true);
  this->logPlaybackPub->Publish(msg);
}

```

Declare and advertised the topic before with:

```
this->logPlaybackPub =
    this->node->Advertise<msgs::LogPlaybackControl>("~/playback_control");
```


You can replace the line `msg.set_rewind(true);` with other options:

  1. Forward:

```
msg.set_forward(true);
```
 
 1. Seek: 

```
  msg.mutable_seek()->set_sec(<VALUE_IN_SIM_SECS>);
  msg.mutable_seek()->set_nsec(<VALUE_IN_SIM_NSECS>);
```

Probably, the next pull request will be a new `gazebo::test::ServerFixture::Lload()` function that can load a world from a log file. Then, we could add a few tests for the functionality added in this pull request.

Test results:

1. [No GPU is clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/356/).
1. [Trusty GPU is clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/276/).
1. [Homebrew is clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/263/).
values.title: Log playback: rewind, forward, seek

summary.raw:
This pull request adds the backend implementation for:

  1. Rewind: The simulation starts from the beginning.
  1. Forward: The simulation jumps to the end of the log file.
  1. Seek: The simulation jumps to a specific point specified by its simulation time.

There's still no easy way to test it until we have all the GUI changes merged. This is how you can do it:

Replace `MainWindow.cc::Step()` with this snippet:


```
#!c++
void MainWindow::Step()
{
  msgs::LogPlaybackControl msg;
  msg.set_rewind(true);
  this->logPlaybackPub->Publish(msg);
}

```

Declare and advertised the topic before with:

```
this->logPlaybackPub =
    this->node->Advertise<msgs::LogPlaybackControl>("~/playback_control");
```


You can replace the line `msg.set_rewind(true);` with other options:

  1. Forward:

```
msg.set_forward(true);
```
 
 1. Seek: 

```
  msg.mutable_seek()->set_sec(<VALUE_IN_SIM_SECS>);
  msg.mutable_seek()->set_nsec(<VALUE_IN_SIM_NSECS>);
```

Probably, the next pull request will be a new `gazebo::test::ServerFixture::Lload()` function that can load a world from a log file. Then, we could add a few tests for the functionality added in this pull request.

Test results:

1. [No GPU is clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/356/).
1. [Trusty GPU is clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/276/).
1. [Homebrew is clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/263/).
summary.html:
This pull request adds the backend implementation for:

  1. Rewind: The simulation starts from the beginning.
  2. Forward: The simulation jumps to the end of the log file.
  3. Seek: The simulation jumps to a specific point specified by its simulation time.

There's still no easy way to test it until we have all the GUI changes merged. This is how you can do it:

Replace MainWindow.cc::Step() with this snippet:

void MainWindow::Step()
{
  msgs::LogPlaybackControl msg;
  msg.set_rewind(true);
  this->logPlaybackPub->Publish(msg);
}

Declare and advertised the topic before with:

this->logPlaybackPub =
    this->node->Advertise<msgs::LogPlaybackControl>("~/playback_control");

You can replace the line msg.set_rewind(true); with other options:

  1. Forward:
msg.set_forward(true);
  1. Seek: 
  msg.mutable_seek()->set_sec(<VALUE_IN_SIM_SECS>);
  msg.mutable_seek()->set_nsec(<VALUE_IN_SIM_NSECS>);

Probably, the next pull request will be a new gazebo::test::ServerFixture::Lload() function that can load a world from a log file. Then, we could add a few tests for the functionality added in this pull request.

Test results:

  1. No GPU is clean.
  2. Trusty GPU is clean.
  3. Homebrew is clean.

values.description:
This plugin allows objects to automatically move from one location to another. Look at `TransporterPlugin.hh` for a description.

[No gpu clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/358)

[Nvidia clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/278)

[Homebrew  clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/264) Although the test doesn't run due to a protobuf issue

```
#!c++


 libc++abi.dylib: terminating with uncaught exception of type google::protobuf::FatalException: CHECK failed: generated_database_->Add(encoded_file_descriptor, size):
```

values.description: Allows plugins, tools, and events to be built on windows. Fixed dll imports/exports, added windows specfic includes (mostly winsock), and fixed code style to work on windows. Everything could be built if it were linked statically, but this is not what we want. This will be fixed as soon as some circular dependencies are resolved.For now plugin and event libraries are kept as SHARED so that it will build on Linux.
values.title: Fixing windows compilation

summary.raw: Allows plugins, tools, and events to be built on windows. Fixed dll imports/exports, added windows specfic includes (mostly winsock), and fixed code style to work on windows. Everything could be built if it were linked statically, but this is not what we want. This will be fixed as soon as some circular dependencies are resolved.For now plugin and event libraries are kept as SHARED so that it will build on Linux.
summary.html: Allows plugins, tools, and events to be built on windows. Fixed dll imports/exports, added windows specfic includes (mostly winsock), and fixed code style to work on windows. Everything could be built if it were linked statically, but this is not what we want. This will be fixed as soon as some circular dependencies are resolved.For now plugin and event libraries are kept as SHARED so that it will build on Linux.

values.description:
Related to issue [1363](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/1363/add-measurement-units-to-inspector).   
This pull request fixes measurement unit for inspector windows in Building Editor:   
1. Add measurement unit `m` for `length`, `height`, `thickness`.     
2. Align numbers to the right 
3. Reorder the `lengthLabel` to be in place with the order in the inspector.  
4. Remove the comment `Distance from Start to End point`.   
5. Change the `length` property from  `QGroupBox`  to `QGridLayout`.   
6. Add a dummy label to both `color` and `texture` field for alignment purpose.
values.title: Add measurement unit to inspectors for Building Editor

summary.raw:
Related to issue [1363](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/1363/add-measurement-units-to-inspector).   
This pull request fixes measurement unit for inspector windows in Building Editor:   
1. Add measurement unit `m` for `length`, `height`, `thickness`.     
2. Align numbers to the right 
3. Reorder the `lengthLabel` to be in place with the order in the inspector.  
4. Remove the comment `Distance from Start to End point`.   
5. Change the `length` property from  `QGroupBox`  to `QGridLayout`.   
6. Add a dummy label to both `color` and `texture` field for alignment purpose.

This pull request fixes measurement unit for inspector windows in Building Editor:
1. Add measurement unit m for length, height, thickness.
2. Align numbers to the right 3. Reorder the lengthLabel to be in place with the order in the inspector.
4. Remove the comment Distance from Start to End point.
5. Change the length property from QGroupBox to QGridLayout.
6. Add a dummy label to both color and texture field for alignment purpose.

values.description:
It passes the necessary environment variables to the tests:

* `CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH`
* `GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH`
* `GAZEBO_RESOURCE_PATH`
* `PATH`
* `PKG_CONFIG_PATH`

`test/pkgconfig` did not check if the correct Gazebo version was found. It also didn't clean the temporary build folder and therefore reused CMakeCache information from previous test runs.
values.title: update most tests to work without installing

* `CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH`
* `GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH`
* `GAZEBO_RESOURCE_PATH`
* `PATH`
* `PKG_CONFIG_PATH`

`test/pkgconfig` did not check if the correct Gazebo version was found. It also didn't clean the temporary build folder and therefore reused CMakeCache information from previous test runs.
summary.html:
It passes the necessary environment variables to the tests:

  • CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH
  • GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH
  • GAZEBO_RESOURCE_PATH
  • PATH
  • PKG_CONFIG_PATH

test/pkgconfig did not check if the correct Gazebo version was found. It also didn't clean the temporary build folder and therefore reused CMakeCache information from previous test runs.

values.description: this PR will add a splash screen to the gazebo startup, so that something will happen for the user while it is downloading models. then impatient users (like me) won't think it's broken and ctrl+C the program before it starts up.
values.title: splash screen

values.description:
[sdformat pull request 190](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/190/fix-detection-of-xml-parsing-errors/diff#comment-7713790) improves detection of xml syntax errors in sdformat. I discovered a [number of errors in gazebo's default branch](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-sdformat-any-devel-trusty-amd64/7/) using the `gazebo-any-sdformat-any` job.

This branch [fixes those test failures](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-sdformat-any-devel-trusty-amd64/12).

* I ran `code_check.sh` and found no errors
* I ran the trusty `gazebo-any-sdformat-any` job instead of the `no-gpu` or `nvidia` jobs since the custom sdformat branch was necessary to see failures.
* I tested the fixes on homebrew on my laptop to confirm the test fixes
* I haven't tried the code on Windows due to [sdformat issue 97](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/issue/97/windows-linking-error)
values.title: Fix xml  syntax errors

summary.raw:
[sdformat pull request 190](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/190/fix-detection-of-xml-parsing-errors/diff#comment-7713790) improves detection of xml syntax errors in sdformat. I discovered a [number of errors in gazebo's default branch](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-sdformat-any-devel-trusty-amd64/7/) using the `gazebo-any-sdformat-any` job.

This branch [fixes those test failures](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-sdformat-any-devel-trusty-amd64/12).

* I ran `code_check.sh` and found no errors
* I ran the trusty `gazebo-any-sdformat-any` job instead of the `no-gpu` or `nvidia` jobs since the custom sdformat branch was necessary to see failures.
* I tested the fixes on homebrew on my laptop to confirm the test fixes
* I haven't tried the code on Windows due to [sdformat issue 97](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/issue/97/windows-linking-error)
summary.html:
sdformat pull request 190 improves detection of xml syntax errors in sdformat. I discovered a number of errors in gazebo's default branch using the gazebo-any-sdformat-any job.

This branch fixes those test failures.

  • I ran code_check.sh and found no errors
  • I ran the trusty gazebo-any-sdformat-any job instead of the no-gpu or nvidia jobs since the custom sdformat branch was necessary to see failures.
  • I tested the fixes on homebrew on my laptop to confirm the test fixes
  • I haven't tried the code on Windows due to sdformat issue 97

values.description:
The `BaseInspectorDialog` is ued to reduce the code duplication for other dialogs in build editor:   
`color` and `texture` related member variable and functions are moved to `BaseInspectorDialog`  

The branch has merged with [issue_1363](https://bitbucket.org/rosebudflyaway/gazebo/branch/issue_1363) to resolve some conflicts   

`code_check.sh` run with `0` errors  

[Jenkins build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-external-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/18/)

values.description:
This is the code that creates an altitude sensor. On initialization the sensor marks its current altitude (position along the global Z axis) as the reference height. Then it reports the vertical displacement with respect to this reference point, as well as the vertical velocity.

It requires this [sdformat pull request](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/197/added-altimeter-sensor-to-sdf/diff) and forms part of the [sensor improvement](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/pull-request/19/improve-sensor-noise-models) design documents.
values.title: Add altimeter sensor plus test

summary.raw:
This is the code that creates an altitude sensor. On initialization the sensor marks its current altitude (position along the global Z axis) as the reference height. Then it reports the vertical displacement with respect to this reference point, as well as the vertical velocity.

It requires this [sdformat pull request](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/197/added-altimeter-sensor-to-sdf/diff) and forms part of the [sensor improvement](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/pull-request/19/improve-sensor-noise-models) design documents.
summary.html:
This is the code that creates an altitude sensor. On initialization the sensor marks its current altitude (position along the global Z axis) as the reference height. Then it reports the vertical displacement with respect to this reference point, as well as the vertical velocity.

It requires this sdformat pull request and forms part of the sensor improvement design documents.
